response.answer_text: It seems you have the wrong idea of what math is, and are confused between the essence of math and the tools employed in math. It’s hard to define what math is, but a popular definition is that math is the study of quantity, structure, space, and change. Taking your rocket example, you definitely need to know how much fuel to put in it (quantity), how it moves around in space, how its mass and velocity changes, and so on. So no matter what you do, if you want to be able to launch that rocket, there’s no getting around doing math. How you do math is a different matter. Modern math is full of symbols and formulas, and has come to be associated with them. But you can do math using words alone if you’re so inclined, and there were times when that was how it was done. The reason that we’ve switched to using formulas is that mathematicians are lazy, and they have found that doing math with formulas is much, much, much easier. Much. To give an example, there was a time where to solve a quadratic equation, you would say something like “To find a thing such that the thing squared multiplied by a number, plus the thing multiplied by a second number, plus a third number, is equal to zero, let the thing be the ratio of two terms, the second term being twice the first number, the first term being the negative of the second number, plus or minus the square root of the difference between the square of the second number and four times the product of the first and third numbers”. Nowadays we just say “The solution to ax2+bx+c=0ax2+bx+c=0 is x=−b±b2−4ac√2ax=−b±b2−4ac2a". Tell me, which way is easier to actually use, develop and work with? Which is more applicable to problems much, much harder than simply solving quadratic equations? You won’t progress much if you impose upon yourself arbitrary restrictions on top of the problem at hand, such as avoiding using symbols.

Math is all around us.When I was young, my father (who was a food broker) posed simple math problems in the grocery store (in the days before there were informational tags on grocery products). They were of the form: If product A is 12 oz and the cost is $7.20 but Product B is 16 oz and the cost is $8.00, which is the better buy? This was in the 60's before hand calculators - decide using mental arithmetic. You are driving from New Jersey to Boston. The distance is 350 miles. You are going at 75 miles an hour (more or less). How many hours does it take to get there? Most financial transactions take math. Your retirement fund depends on math - if you have any sense at all. Math is required in analyzing risk. Humans are especially bad at statistical analysis. I once had this case: I am a chronic depressive. I am on a Selective Serotonin Uptake Inhibitor (SSRI). There have been about 5 cases of liver failure using this SSRI. There have been over a million patients on the drug. If I stop using the drug, I may get depressed and think of suicide. According to medical studies 15% of those who are clinically depressed die by suicide. If I stay on the drug, what are my chances of dying of liver failure. If I quit the drug, what are my chances of dying by suicide?

So let me give you a slightly different answer. Can math be replaced by something else? The key here is abstraction.  Without abstraction, you have individual fingers and individual toes, and that's about as much as you can say about them.  But if you're able to abstract, you can think about your individual fingers has having some shared property that allows you to think of them as a set called fingers, and likewise for toes.   And if you've gotten that far you can start thinking about abstracting from the sets themselves:  most people can create a one-to-one correspondence from each member of the group fingers to each member of the group toes. That particular abstraction is a number.   So at this very basic level, anytime you perform this kind of "abstraction of an abstraction", you're well into what we understand as mathematics.  You can change the labels, but the underlying concept is going to be the same. Is there another way to describe launching a rocket into orbit? Actually, yes.  The mathematics you learning in school depends on there being an infinite number of numbers, and this leads to (comparatively) well-behaved theorems.  Finite computers can only make use of a vanishingly small number of the numbers we need, and so we end up using something that looks a lot like math from 20 yards on a running horse, but actually is quite different.  On your computer, a+(b+c) does not necessarily equal (a+b)+c.  Is this a different kind of mathematics?  Or an approximation of mathematics?  Either way, it's not the mathematics you were raised with, yet we can use it to go to the moon. What happens if math is not taught as a basic subject? People who can afford to send their children to the best schools will make sure their children are taught mathematics, because an understanding of mathematics makes you more powerful out in the world.  If there is a certain class of people who you would like to keep from attaining power, teach them literacy if you must but definitely don't teach them math.

I hear it stated a lot that “we” don’t need maths in everyday life. Now, I fully accept that there are many people that do not consciously use maths on a daily basis. Although, I would assert that MOST use basic arithmetic every time they go shopping or work out how much to tip a waitress. But when some people state “WE” don’t need maths, they are actually talking about the human race in general, and with that I couldn’t disagree more. The computer that I’m typing this response on would not exist without the hundreds of years of study that the human race has put into mathematics. Every time I hit a key, the computer performs what could be described as an algebraic function, mapping the keystroke to a letter - in my case, via the standard English QWERTY layout. But, I can very easily change that layout to US, German, Korean, if I like. That customisable mapping is ostensibly a result of the concept of algebra. The same goes for every single one of the millions of operations that the computer is carrying out per second. The same goes for the mobile phone in your hand or pocket. In a world where humans never discovered and studied maths, there would be no internal combustion engine. There would be no traffic lights, no controlled production of, or harnessing of electricity … On a VERY fundamental level, the knowledge of mathematics, along with the applied knowledge of physics and chemistry, is responsible for 99% of everything we, as citizens of civilised countries use every day. Not to mention the applications of mathematics in medicine. The fact that people don’t either die of an overdose or wake up in agony during surgical procedures is a result of the use of a mathematical equation taking in variables such as age, weight, length of operation, to determine appropriate doses. Yes. We need maths. It’s pretty ridiculous to suggest otherwise.

Any system that accomplishes the same ends as math essentially is math. So your question is really about whether humanity could have done a better job developing the language, notation, and mental models that support mathematical thinking. I have little doubt that some regrettable decisions have become entrenched (using π rather than 2π as the circle constant, perhaps), but in my view these issues are mostly quite minor. By and large, the mathematical community is pretty good at replacing inefficient or unwieldy ideas with better ones. As a result, our current approach to math is remarkably simple and elegant, considering how much you can do with it. For a contrasting view, I recommend having a look at the Kill Math project: http://worrydream.com/KillMath/

It’s the part of mathematics that deals with numbers and their interactions. Adding, subtracting, multiplication, division, etc. certainly important for all of us to some degree. It has been said that arithmetic is to mathematics the same way that spelling is to writing. Mathematics is more complex and includes solving algebraic equations, understanding differential equations, number theory, geometry, trigonometry and much more. I believe many people use mathematics without realizing it. Carpenters use the Pythagorean theory to make sure their buildings are square. Payroll systems use algebra to calculate the pay for hourly workers. So, whether an individual person uses math or not depends on the person. Without math, airplanes would not fly, buildings would not stand tall and cars would not operate. So whether you need math or not is dependent on your life and what you do. The collective “we” would revert back to caveman status without math.

Maths is an ‘expanded language’. Everything you see being done in the notation of mathematics could be written out in the words of whatever language you want to use. Of course, even the slimmest textbook would have enough volume. Judging by your comments, what you’re thinking of when you talk about ‘maths’ is the notation it uses. But there are already lots of different notations, often operating in the same field at the same time. This can be extremely confusing and controversial unless the context is absolutely clear. One of my current tutors, for example, absolutely insists that I cleave to the 19th century tradition of using Gothic font to signify a certain mathematical object called an ‘ideal’- but at least two of the textbooks I’m using don’t do this and one of them actually seems to have a problem with it, calling it ‘fascist’ lettering’. Basically, notation is only informally standardised (although with the rise of LaTeX it would seem that the American Mathematical Society has sort of become a de facto centralised repository of the most common forms via its standard packages for the tool). I suppose, then, there’s an interesting question as to whether it’s possible to have an optimal - or at least better - notation for any given field. I don’t know how much academic work goes into this - I’d certainly find a cultural history of the development of mathematical notation absolutely fascinating. To answer the final question in your comment, if mathematics itself was not taught as a basic subject, civilisation would collapse. That might not have been true a few hundred years ago, but it certainly is now.

Quite aside from number crunching, maths is about relationships and patterns.   Consider yourself as a human living in tribe centuries ago.  Think of your basic needs. Food:  What types of food are available and when?  Can you store it: how long before different types of food spoil?  How will you plan for scarcity?  How will you predict seasons when food is scarce?  When you figure out that you can plant crops, how do you know when to do it?  How will you measure time?  How will you keep count of time?  What is time? Shelter: It would be nice if it were stable and a storm didn't blow it to pieces and result in you dying of exposure.  Where are you?  Where's the other stuff: water, food, building materials? Security:  Does the other tribe over there look a bit mean and are you standing on "their" land?  Negotiation time: where is the border?  Do both tribes agree on where it is?  Can you trade resources?  Can you get back in time from hunting before it's dark, thus avoiding being eaten? Fast forward and we're navigating the world, there's global trade, information exchange......maths allows us to make sense of the world and how it works.  It's a basic survival skill.
It’s not in maslow’s pyramid, so you actually don’t need it. In experience however, it's pretty darn convenient to know math as it is omnipresent and extremely powerful.
